title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Hyperglycemia is less common than hypoglycemia among neonates, but it is essential to address it because it increases mortality and morbidity among neonates. To avoid the high morbidity and mortality associated with neonatal hyperglycemia, it must be promptly diagnosed and treated. This activity reviews the evaluation and treatment of neonatal hyperglycemia and highlights the interprofessional team's role in evaluating and treating patients with this condition.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Continuing Education Activity. Hyperglycemia is less common than hypoglycemia among neonates, but it is essential to address it because it increases mortality and morbidity among neonates. To avoid the high morbidity and mortality associated with neonatal hyperglycemia, it must be promptly diagnosed and treated. This activity reviews the evaluation and treatment of neonatal hyperglycemia and highlights the interprofessional team's role in evaluating and treating patients with this condition.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of neonatal hyperglycemia. Summarize the management approach for neonatal hyperglycemia. Review the complications of neonatal hyperglycemia. Outline some interprofessional team strategies that can improve outcomes for patients with neonatal hypoglycemia. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of neonatal hyperglycemia. Summarize the management approach for neonatal hyperglycemia. Review the complications of neonatal hyperglycemia. Outline some interprofessional team strategies that can improve outcomes for patients with neonatal hypoglycemia. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Introduction
content: Neonatal hyperglycemia is usually defined as serum glucose greater than 150 mg/dl (8.3 mmol/L) or whole blood glucose greater than 125 mg/dl (6.9 mmol/L) irrespective of gestational or postmenstrual age. Usually, the safe target for a neonate’s blood glucose level is 70 to 150 mg/dl. [1] The cut off for safe target is based on the renal glucose threshold of preterm neonates.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Introduction. Neonatal hyperglycemia is usually defined as serum glucose greater than 150 mg/dl (8.3 mmol/L) or whole blood glucose greater than 125 mg/dl (6.9 mmol/L) irrespective of gestational or postmenstrual age. Usually, the safe target for a neonate’s blood glucose level is 70 to 150 mg/dl. [1] The cut off for safe target is based on the renal glucose threshold of preterm neonates.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Prematurity and Intrauterine growth restriction
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Prematurity and Intrauterine growth restriction

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Inadequate insulin secretion and inability to suppress glucose production in the liver Increased insulin resistance
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Inadequate insulin secretion and inability to suppress glucose production in the liver Increased insulin resistance

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Increased stress hormones like epinephrine and norepinephrine inhibit both insulin secretion and action. They also increase glucagon, which promotes glycogenolysis. The following conditions are associated with increased stress hormones,
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Increased stress hormones like epinephrine and norepinephrine inhibit both insulin secretion and action. They also increase glucagon, which promotes glycogenolysis. The following conditions are associated with increased stress hormones,

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Catecholamine infusions Seizures Physiologic stress caused by surgery, pain, hypoxia, respiratory distress, or sepsis
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Catecholamine infusions Seizures Physiologic stress caused by surgery, pain, hypoxia, respiratory distress, or sepsis

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Causes related to enteral feeding
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Causes related to enteral feeding

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Delay in the initiation of enteral feeding causes decreased incretin secretion, which in turn causes hyperglycemia. [2] The hyperosmolar formula may lead to transient glucose intolerance in the baby.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Delay in the initiation of enteral feeding causes decreased incretin secretion, which in turn causes hyperglycemia. [2] The hyperosmolar formula may lead to transient glucose intolerance in the baby.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Causes related to Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Causes related to Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Delay in supplementing parenteral amino acids in TPN delays the release of insulin-like growth factor-1, which delays the development of beta cells in the pancreas and develops hyperglycemia. A high intravenous lipid infusion rate causes an increase in free fatty acids (FFA), which decrease glucose oxidation competitively by providing additional carbon substrates for oxidative metabolism. FFA and glycerol promote gluconeogenesis. [3]
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Delay in supplementing parenteral amino acids in TPN delays the release of insulin-like growth factor-1, which delays the development of beta cells in the pancreas and develops hyperglycemia. A high intravenous lipid infusion rate causes an increase in free fatty acids (FFA), which decrease glucose oxidation competitively by providing additional carbon substrates for oxidative metabolism. FFA and glycerol promote gluconeogenesis. [3]

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Sepsis: Consider sepsis and Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) if hyperglycemia develops without glucose infusion rate change.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Sepsis: Consider sepsis and Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) if hyperglycemia develops without glucose infusion rate change.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Iatrogenic: One of the causes of hyperglycemia in the neonate is an error in the glucose infusion rate (GIR) calculation in the intravenous (IV) fluids.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Iatrogenic: One of the causes of hyperglycemia in the neonate is an error in the glucose infusion rate (GIR) calculation in the intravenous (IV) fluids.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Transient neonatal diabetes mellitus usually occurs in small for gestational age (SGA) infants. This condition is self-limited.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Transient neonatal diabetes mellitus usually occurs in small for gestational age (SGA) infants. This condition is self-limited.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology
content: Drugs Maternal medications Maternal diazoxide may cause hyperglycemia, hypotension, and tachycardia in neonates. Antenatal steroids Neonatal medications Dopamine, dobutamine, epinephrine infusions Caffeine, theophylline Phenytoin Corticosteroids
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Etiology. Drugs Maternal medications Maternal diazoxide may cause hyperglycemia, hypotension, and tachycardia in neonates. Antenatal steroids Neonatal medications Dopamine, dobutamine, epinephrine infusions Caffeine, theophylline Phenytoin Corticosteroids

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Epidemiology
content: Hyperglycemia is more common in preterm infants than term infants and is generally noted during the first week of life. Usually, the acute hyperglycemia resolves over two to three days in most neonates but can last up to ten days. Hyperglycemia is less common than hypoglycemia among neonates but is associated with increased mortality and morbidity among neonates. Neonatal hyperglycemia is inversely related to birth weight and gestational age. [4] Hyperglycemia occurs in one-third of preterm and SGA infants.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Epidemiology. Hyperglycemia is more common in preterm infants than term infants and is generally noted during the first week of life. Usually, the acute hyperglycemia resolves over two to three days in most neonates but can last up to ten days. Hyperglycemia is less common than hypoglycemia among neonates but is associated with increased mortality and morbidity among neonates. Neonatal hyperglycemia is inversely related to birth weight and gestational age. [4] Hyperglycemia occurs in one-third of preterm and SGA infants.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Pathophysiology
content: Glucose is an essential source of energy for the fetus and neonate. The brain growth of the fetus exclusively depends upon glucose. In the early postnatal period, glucose homeostasis occurs via glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. The critical regulatory mechanisms of glucose homeostasis are sluggish in the initial days, particularly among preterm neonates. The mechanisms of neonatal hyperglycemia are multifactorial. The risk of hyperglycemia increases with the severity of the accompanying illness. The most common cause is high exogenous glucose infusion rates in preterm infants who are already at risk for hyperglycemia due to the following reasons, decreased ability to suppress endogenous glucose production, decreased insulin response to glucose, and limited glycogen and fat stores. [5]
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Pathophysiology. Glucose is an essential source of energy for the fetus and neonate. The brain growth of the fetus exclusively depends upon glucose. In the early postnatal period, glucose homeostasis occurs via glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. The critical regulatory mechanisms of glucose homeostasis are sluggish in the initial days, particularly among preterm neonates. The mechanisms of neonatal hyperglycemia are multifactorial. The risk of hyperglycemia increases with the severity of the accompanying illness. The most common cause is high exogenous glucose infusion rates in preterm infants who are already at risk for hyperglycemia due to the following reasons, decreased ability to suppress endogenous glucose production, decreased insulin response to glucose, and limited glycogen and fat stores. [5]

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- History and Physical
content: There are no specific findings related to hyperglycemia. Physical examination may reveal signs of the underlying cause, for example, temperature instability and low perfusion in sepsis. The following signs, though nonspecific, may indicate hyperglycemia. Increased urine output Dehydration Weight loss Fever Feeding difficulty
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- History and Physical. There are no specific findings related to hyperglycemia. Physical examination may reveal signs of the underlying cause, for example, temperature instability and low perfusion in sepsis. The following signs, though nonspecific, may indicate hyperglycemia. Increased urine output Dehydration Weight loss Fever Feeding difficulty

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Evaluation -- Considerations for workup should include:
content: Serum glucose: Relying on point-of-care blood glucose testing alone will yield erroneous results. A high blood glucose level must be verified by measuring the serum glucose level before starting treatment for neonatal hyperglycemia. Venous blood glucose measurement is a preferred sample compared to capillary blood glucose measurement. Capillary blood glucose (heel stick sample) is 15% lower, and the hematocrit value affects the levels. Urine glucose 2+ or higher suggests osmotic diuresis. Complete blood count and C-reactive protein will help in ruling out sepsis. Monitor serum electrolytes levels in patients with hyperglycemia. The osmotic diuresis causes electrolyte loss in urine. Measure the weight of the baby to determine hydration status. If hyperglycemia is persistent, serum insulin level, serum, and urine C-peptide levels are used to rule out monogenic diabetes and Type 1 diabetes.

Venous blood glucose measurement is a preferred sample compared to capillary blood glucose measurement. Capillary blood glucose (heel stick sample) is 15% lower, and the hematocrit value affects the levels. Urine glucose 2+ or higher suggests osmotic diuresis. Complete blood count and C-reactive protein will help in ruling out sepsis. Monitor serum electrolytes levels in patients with hyperglycemia. The osmotic diuresis causes electrolyte loss in urine. Measure the weight of the baby to determine hydration status. If hyperglycemia is persistent, serum insulin level, serum, and urine C-peptide levels are used to rule out monogenic diabetes and Type 1 diabetes.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: In preterm and very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants, i.e., infants with birth weight less than 1500 grams, a consistent blood glucose level of more than 200 mg/dL is a cause for concern. A blood glucose level measured as >200 mg/dL with a 4-hour interval and glucosuria of +2 or more necessitates treatment. Currently, hyperglycemia treatment in the absence of an increase in osmolarity and osmotic diuresis is not supported.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management. In preterm and very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants, i.e., infants with birth weight less than 1500 grams, a consistent blood glucose level of more than 200 mg/dL is a cause for concern. A blood glucose level measured as >200 mg/dL with a 4-hour interval and glucosuria of +2 or more necessitates treatment. Currently, hyperglycemia treatment in the absence of an increase in osmolarity and osmotic diuresis is not supported.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: The first step in evaluating neonatal hyperglycemia is to assess the GIR. GIR = IV infusion rate (mL/kg/day) x Dextrose concentration (%) / 144 The GIR is lowered by reducing IV dextrose concentration or the infusion rate. GIR can be decreased by 1 to 2 mg/kg/min every 2 hours, with frequent glucose monitoring until the GIR reaches 4 mg/kg/min.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management. The first step in evaluating neonatal hyperglycemia is to assess the GIR. GIR = IV infusion rate (mL/kg/day) x Dextrose concentration (%) / 144 The GIR is lowered by reducing IV dextrose concentration or the infusion rate. GIR can be decreased by 1 to 2 mg/kg/min every 2 hours, with frequent glucose monitoring until the GIR reaches 4 mg/kg/min.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: In case of persistent hyperglycemia, underlying causes such as sepsis, stress, medications need to be explored and treated accordingly. [6]
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management. In case of persistent hyperglycemia, underlying causes such as sepsis, stress, medications need to be explored and treated accordingly. [6]

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: Role of Insulin Hyperglycemia persisting at low GIR (4 mg/kg/min) may indicate relative insulin deficiency or insulin resistance. The role of insulin therapy in treating hyperglycemia in neonates is controversial. Consider insulin if blood glucose level is more than 250 mg/dl, and if urine glucose is more than 2+ in two separate samples obtained four hours apart. Bolus insulin therapy has a high risk of causing hypoglycemia. So, bolus insulin therapy is usually not preferred in treating neonatal hyperglycemia. Two approaches are available for using Insulin. The first approach is to add insulin to maintenance fluids. Another approach is to run insulin independently. This approach's advantage is that the insulin rate can be adjusted without changing the total IV fluid rate. The dosage of Insulin The initial dosage for insulin infusion is 0.01 to 0.05 U/kg/hour. Titrate the insulin infusion rate based on blood glucose concentrations Titrate the insulin with an increment of 0.01 U/kg/h. The maximum dose can be up to 0.1 U/kg/h. The target is to maintain the blood glucose level between 100 mg/dL and 150 mg/dL. [7] If the blood glucose level decreases to 180 mg/dL, insulin infusion is reduced by 50%. If the blood glucose level is below 150 mg/dL, discontinue the Insulin. It is crucial to monitor serum glucose levels every 1 hour when the infant is on insulin. Measure the blood glucose level half an hour after each change in insulin infusion If hypoglycemia develops, discontinue the insulin infusion and give 2 ml/kg D10 IV bolus. After discontinuing the Insulin, monitor for rebound hyperglycemia.

The first approach is to add insulin to maintenance fluids. Another approach is to run insulin independently. This approach's advantage is that the insulin rate can be adjusted without changing the total IV fluid rate. The dosage of Insulin The initial dosage for insulin infusion is 0.01 to 0.05 U/kg/hour. Titrate the insulin infusion rate based on blood glucose concentrations Titrate the insulin with an increment of 0.01 U/kg/h. The maximum dose can be up to 0.1 U/kg/h. The target is to maintain the blood glucose level between 100 mg/dL and 150 mg/dL. [7] If the blood glucose level decreases to 180 mg/dL, insulin infusion is reduced by 50%. If the blood glucose level is below 150 mg/dL, discontinue the Insulin. It is crucial to monitor serum glucose levels every 1 hour when the infant is on insulin. Measure the blood glucose level half an hour after each change in insulin infusion If hypoglycemia develops, discontinue the insulin infusion and give 2 ml/kg D10 IV bolus. After discontinuing the Insulin, monitor for rebound hyperglycemia.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: Any electrolyte imbalance due to osmotic diuresis should be corrected. Sodium and potassium imbalance is very common.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management. Any electrolyte imbalance due to osmotic diuresis should be corrected. Sodium and potassium imbalance is very common.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management
content: Hyperglycemia needs to be prevented in all neonates, particularly among preterm infants, due to associated complications such as the increased risk for infection, impaired immunity, poor wound healing, increased morbidity, and mortality. The following preventive measures help in the practice to prevent hyperglycemia. Early initiation of enteral feedings Early supplementation of amino acids in TPN, leading to an increase in insulin secretion that prevents hyperglycemia. Targeting optimal and physiologic GIR in TPN as per the glucose monitoring Limiting IV lipid infusions during hyperglycemia A more direct and immediate approach is to decrease the catecholamine infusions as tolerated. Discontinuing catecholamine infusions and glucocorticoid treatments as soon as the infant's condition has improved.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Treatment / Management. Hyperglycemia needs to be prevented in all neonates, particularly among preterm infants, due to associated complications such as the increased risk for infection, impaired immunity, poor wound healing, increased morbidity, and mortality. The following preventive measures help in the practice to prevent hyperglycemia. Early initiation of enteral feedings Early supplementation of amino acids in TPN, leading to an increase in insulin secretion that prevents hyperglycemia. Targeting optimal and physiologic GIR in TPN as per the glucose monitoring Limiting IV lipid infusions during hyperglycemia A more direct and immediate approach is to decrease the catecholamine infusions as tolerated. Discontinuing catecholamine infusions and glucocorticoid treatments as soon as the infant's condition has improved.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Differential Diagnosis
content: In general, Neonatal hyperglycemia is associated with a clinical condition rather than a specific disorder of glucose metabolism. Neonatal hyperglycemia can be a sign of an underlying illness like sepsis, NEC, seizures. A rare cause of neonatal hyperglycemia is neonatal diabetes mellitus. Neonatal diabetes can occur in one in 400,000 births. [8] Neonatal diabetes can be of three different types. The transient form accounts for more than 50%. It is usually associated with mutations of sulfonylurea receptors. Transient neonatal diabetes manifests soon after birth and remits spontaneously in 6 months. Permanent neonatal diabetes needs lifelong management. Mutations in the genes encoding the subunit of the ATP-sensitive potassium channel is the most common cause. [9] Syndromic Neonatal diabetes is usually associated with syndromes like Wolfram syndrome, IPEX syndrome (immune dysregulation polyendocrinopathy X linked syndrome).
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Differential Diagnosis. In general, Neonatal hyperglycemia is associated with a clinical condition rather than a specific disorder of glucose metabolism. Neonatal hyperglycemia can be a sign of an underlying illness like sepsis, NEC, seizures. A rare cause of neonatal hyperglycemia is neonatal diabetes mellitus. Neonatal diabetes can occur in one in 400,000 births. [8] Neonatal diabetes can be of three different types. The transient form accounts for more than 50%. It is usually associated with mutations of sulfonylurea receptors. Transient neonatal diabetes manifests soon after birth and remits spontaneously in 6 months. Permanent neonatal diabetes needs lifelong management. Mutations in the genes encoding the subunit of the ATP-sensitive potassium channel is the most common cause. [9] Syndromic Neonatal diabetes is usually associated with syndromes like Wolfram syndrome, IPEX syndrome (immune dysregulation polyendocrinopathy X linked syndrome).

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Prognosis
content: Neonatal hyperglycemia, particularly in preterm neonates, is usually associated with an increased risk of mortality and morbidity. The severity of impact increases with prolonged hyperglycemia. Prompt evaluation and management of neonatal hyperglycemia decrease the impact.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Prognosis. Neonatal hyperglycemia, particularly in preterm neonates, is usually associated with an increased risk of mortality and morbidity. The severity of impact increases with prolonged hyperglycemia. Prompt evaluation and management of neonatal hyperglycemia decrease the impact.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications
content: Increased mortality risk among preterm and VLBW infants
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications. Increased mortality risk among preterm and VLBW infants

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications
content: Increased morbidity among preterm infants. More severe outcomes occur with prolonged hyperglycemia. Neonates with hyperglycemia have an increased risk of following, Intracranial hemorrhage Hyperglycemia may cause Intracranial hemorrhage by causing hyperosmolarity with osmotic shifts. [10] Each increment of 18 mg/dL in blood glucose concentration accounts for a rise of 1 mOsm/L in serum osmolarity.  If serum osmolarity exceeds 300 mOsm/L, rapidly shifting water may cause cerebral hemorrhage. Dehydration due to osmotic diuresis Electrolyte imbalance occurs due to osmotic diuresis. Glycosuria also increases sodium excretion. NEC [11] Retinopathy of prematurity [12] Bronchopulmonary disease Impaired immunity and increased risk of sepsis Poor wound healing
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications. Increased morbidity among preterm infants. More severe outcomes occur with prolonged hyperglycemia. Neonates with hyperglycemia have an increased risk of following, Intracranial hemorrhage Hyperglycemia may cause Intracranial hemorrhage by causing hyperosmolarity with osmotic shifts. [10] Each increment of 18 mg/dL in blood glucose concentration accounts for a rise of 1 mOsm/L in serum osmolarity.  If serum osmolarity exceeds 300 mOsm/L, rapidly shifting water may cause cerebral hemorrhage. Dehydration due to osmotic diuresis Electrolyte imbalance occurs due to osmotic diuresis. Glycosuria also increases sodium excretion. NEC [11] Retinopathy of prematurity [12] Bronchopulmonary disease Impaired immunity and increased risk of sepsis Poor wound healing

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications
content: Long term impact Adverse neurodevelopmental outcome Insulin resistance and glucose intolerance
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications. Long term impact Adverse neurodevelopmental outcome Insulin resistance and glucose intolerance

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications
content: Side effects due to the management Insulin infusion increases the risks of hypokalemia and hypoglycemia.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Complications. Side effects due to the management Insulin infusion increases the risks of hypokalemia and hypoglycemia.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: Neonatal hyperglycemia is a critical problem noted in premature infants due to the relatively immature mechanisms to handle glucose equilibrium. The parents of preterm and small for gestational age neonates need appropriate counseling as they will be worried about frequent blood glucose monitoring. The health care team should explain the short-term and long-term impacts of neonatal hyperglycemia to the parents.
contents: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Deterrence and Patient Education. Neonatal hyperglycemia is a critical problem noted in premature infants due to the relatively immature mechanisms to handle glucose equilibrium. The parents of preterm and small for gestational age neonates need appropriate counseling as they will be worried about frequent blood glucose monitoring. The health care team should explain the short-term and long-term impacts of neonatal hyperglycemia to the parents.

title: Neonatal Hyperglycemia -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: In the neonatal intensive care unit, physicians, practitioners, and nursing staff taking care of the infants should have a clinical suspicion of neonatal hyperglycemia. The signs and symptoms of neonatal hyperglycemia are often vague and nonspecific. The healthcare team should be aware of the management strategy and complications of neonatal hyperglycemia. The at-risk infants should be monitored closely and treated if the hyperglycemia is severe and persistent to avoid further complications. Early initiation of enteral feeds and optimized parenteral nutrition with adequate amino acid supplementation can prevent neonatal hyperglycemia.

The at-risk infants should be monitored closely and treated if the hyperglycemia is severe and persistent to avoid further complications. Early initiation of enteral feeds and optimized parenteral nutrition with adequate amino acid supplementation can prevent neonatal hyperglycemia.
